titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
I received a printed recommendation signed by W. W. Seaton Mayor of the City and seven others of Joshua L Henshaw as a Candidate for Door Keeper of the House of Representatives and Wm. Whitney an inhabitant of
this City where he says he has resided these five and twenty years, came in person to solicit my vote for himself as Door Keeper of the House of Representatives he being no relation to C. S Whitney the present Door Keeper who is the son of the late Reuben M. Whitney— Joseph Hill the Orphan boy whom I had recommended for the appointment of a Page to the House, was here again with his recommendation from Mr. Donellan Director of St Matthews Church and Mr. N. Callan to which the present Door Keeper C. S. Whitney desired that I would add my recommendation in writing which I did, but told him that he must go to Mr. Donelan and get his assent to the rectification of his name which the boy had made himself. Mr. John Mason junr. Son of General John Mason formerly of Georgetown but now of Virginia was here and I mistook him for his brother James Mason now a Senator from the State of Virginia. I had visits also from Mr. Foster a member of the House and Mr. Thompson member elect from Indiana— Col Kearney came with Mr. Mason who introduced him to me, though he had already been introduced by Col Abert— Theodore Talbot spent the Evening here.

Birth day of my Granddaughter Mary Louisa Adams who enters on her twentieth year. Joseph Grinnell arrived here yesterday and visited us with Robert. C. Winthrop this morning— Robert C. Dyson a boy about 12 years of age brought me a note from Mrs. Colvin his aunt, soliciting my influence to obtain for him the appointment of a Page to the House of Representatives. I desired him to say to Mrs. Colvin that I should be glad if he could succeed in his desire but I had already recommended one and could not expect that my influence would have
no weight for more than one— I would name him to the Doorkeeper, but he would do well to apply for the influence of Members possessing more than mine. Mrs. Shryock a widow solicits employment in the Folding Room of the H.R.U.S. for her son Samuel Shryock sixteen years old, who has lost his father— She does not apply for his appointment as a Page, for which she supposes him to be too old. The Pages being generally between seven and fourteen. Mr. James Buchanan Secretary of State our next door neighbour spent the evening with us—

Awake and heard the clock strike two then slept till the clock struck five, lay awake till Seven then I rose. Returned the visit of Mr. Grinnell at Willards City Hotel and that of Mr. Winthrop at Coleman’s— Miss Louise Agniel arrived in company with Mr. Robert C. Schenck. Evening visit from General Dix member of the Senate from the State of New York.

A multitude of visitors. Some members of Congress others Candidates for Offices to be elected at the organization of Congress and especially of the House of Representatives next Monday. I went to the House of Representatives expecting to meet there some member of the Massachusett Delegation to give him the Letter that I received from Mr. John. P. Kennedy recommending Mr. Otho. H. Williams for the Office of Sergeant at Arms of the House, that might be presented this Evening at the Whig Caucus of members, of the House which Mr. Williams had
requested I would do, but I met no Member from Massachusetts at the House and was thus unable to comply with the request— Mr. Fendall was here in the Evening.

At the Unitarian Church this morning Mr. Allen preached from 2 Timothy 2.22. [“]Follow righteousness, faith, charity, peace with them that call on the Lord out of a pure heart.” the argument of the Discourse was that the test of a true Christian was righteousness, sincerity and purity of heart. In the Afternoon at St John’s Church Mr. Pyne preached and read the Evening Service for the second Sunday in Advent and preached from Proverbs 15.8. “The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination to the Lord; but the prayer of the upright is his delight.” I went again to the Unitarian Church in the Evening when Mr. Allen preached from Galatians 6.7. “Be not deceived God is not mocked; for whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap”— Miss Agniel and Mary Louisa went with me to Church and we met there Mr. Robert. C. Schenck— He told me that the Caucus of last Evening had in the first instance nominated Mr. Samuel. F. Vinton as Candidate for Speaker but he had declined and they had then unanimously nominated Robert. C. Winthrop and they had also with equal unanimity agreed to nominate all the subordinate Officers to be elected by the House. Mrs. George Graham called this morning to invite us to the Wedding of her daughter Miss Graham.

Commencement of the First Session of the 30th. Congress. At the first vote for the choice of Speaker of the House the whole number of
votes was 220. of which Robert. C. Winthrop of Massachusetts had 108. At the second vote the whole number was 219. of which Winthrop had 109. At the third vote the whole number was 118. of which Winthrop at 110. and was chosen. The Oath of Office was administered to him by me and then the same Oath was administered to all the members elect by him— My wife was taken very ill this evening and Dr. Thomas was sent for and assured me that it would not be of serious consequences. It was the effect of extraordinary agitation—with which my own health deeply sympathized.

Mr. Lewis C. Levin a Native American Member from Philadelphia had moved yesterday, that Benjamin B. French the Clerk of the House for the last Congress should be appointed the Clerk for the present Congress. At the last Congress he was so appointed without opposition. This morning Mr. Levin modified his resolution to read “that this House do now proceed to vote viva voce for Clerk”—which was done. Mr. Toombs of Georgia nominated Thomas Jefferson Campbell of Tennessee. Mr. Broadhead nominated Benjamin B. French. Mr. Holmes of South Carolina nominated Samuel L. Gouverneur— The whole number of votes given was 225. necessary to a choice 113. which number was received by Thomas J. Campbell. French received 109. Gouverneur 1. George Kent 1. Mr. Tuck from New Hampshire and Nathan Sergeant 1. Mr. Giddings of Ohio— I voted myself for French having promised him some months since so to do— Several Whigs, a number sufficient to have elected him, had made him the same promise, unless overpowered by the Caucus screw—which was actually applied to them— Campbell was a Member of the 28th. Congress from Tennessee— A resolution was next offered by Alex Evans of Maryland to draw lots for the choice of
choice of seats—which was done. The names of all the Members being put by the Clerk into a box and as each members name was drawn from the box, he selected and took his seat for the Session. My name was early drawn and I took the same seat which I have occupied for the last ten years, no other member having manifested the disposition even to take it—though certainly one of the best seats in the House. Washington Hunt one of the joint Committee on the part of the House to wait on the President and inform him that a Quorum of both Houses had been formed and were ready to receive from him any communication he was pleased to make reported that the President would immediately transmit a Message in writing. It was accordingly immediately presented and read occupying nearly three hours in the reading and the usual resolutions for printing a number of copies, with and without accompanying Documents, were passed— A resolution was passed for fixing the daily hour of meeting of the House, at twelve oclock noon, till farther order— Some debate concerning the Committee for revision of the Rules and a motion to strike out what is called the hour rule, was left undecided— The House adjourned about 4. oclock— My wife was confined by indisposition to her bed all day, but was recovering. Evening visit from Mr. Glück.

Clingman had moved yesterday to lay upon the Table of Henly to reconsider the vote adopting the Rules of the last Congress, excepting the one hour— Clingman withdrew his motion this morning to lay it upon the Table; and the motion to reconsider has passed over until the
third Monday in this month, before which the Committee on the revision of the Rules, are to report Their names have not yet been published in the Intelligencer and I know not who they are— The organization of the House was completed by the choice of Officers—Nathan Sargeant was elected Sergeant At Arms by 116 votes out of 224. Newton Lane the Sergeant at Arms of the last Congress had 96 votes and Charles A. Whitney 12. The next election was of Door Keeper for which Robert. E. Horner received 117. votes and Cornelius. S. Whitney the Door keeper of the last Congress had 107. The last election was of Post Master for which John. M. Johnson the present Post master received 111 votes out of 221. and Wm. J Mc.Cormick 110. Johnson is thus the only officer of the Administration Party re-elected in opposition to the Whig Caucus Candidate— All the Officers have been elected by majorities of one or two votes. My wife was better this day and Dr. Thomas visited us twice.

Morning visit from Dr. Thomas. at eleven oclock I attended at the House. At the meeting of the House Timothy Pillsbury appeared and took a seat as member from Texas. Jameson of Missouri moved that when the House should adjourn it should be over to Monday to give the Speaker time to appoint the standing Committees, which was agreed to— A Resolution moved by Mr. Collamer of Vermont for the appointment of a Joint Committee on the Library— Brodhead gave notice that he would ask leave to introduce a Bill relating to the Postage of newspapers— Pollock of Pennsylvania offered a Resolution for the appointment of two Chaplains one by each House and of different Denominations, against which John Pettit of Indiana made his usual Speech. He offered two Amendments to the Resolution, one to strike out the different Denominations and the other to add, that they should be paid by the members out of their own money—He disputes the Constitutional power to pay for Religious Services
out of the Public Treasury—but he could neither get the yeas or nays, nor any vote besides his own to either of his Amendments— Pollocks resolution was adopted nemine contra disente—except Pettit, there were no small number of other members not voting at all. Henley of Indiana moved the appointment of the standing Committees— Samuel F. Vinton of Ohio moved a series of Resolutions for dividing the Committee of Commerce into two, one for Foreign Commerce and the other Commerce between the States, which immediately gave rise to Debate— In the midst of which I left the House about one oclock to attend with the ladies of our family at the wedding of Miss Jennie Graham daughter of the late George Graham a school companion of my Grand Daughter Mary Louisa— We got to the house just as the Nuptial Ceremony had been performed by the Rev Mr. Pyne— There was a numerous Company present and plenteous cold collation—from which we retired about two oclock

The House adjourned yesterday over to Monday. I had this day several visitors, among whom John P. Hale, senator from New Hampshire George Ashmun member of the House from Massachusetts Truman Smith member from Connecticut, Thomas Clingman member from North Carolina in the morning. Lieut. N. F. Maury Superintendent of the Observatory, the Roman Catholic Bishop of New York Hughes with Mr. Robinson the Reporter of the New York Tribune newspaper— I had received a long Letter from Lieut Maury dated at the National Observatory 17th. Novr. 1847 upon the subject of Astronomy and of the Instruments in use at the Observatory— Bishop Hughes has been called here by the Executive Government to be consulted respecting
negotiations with Mexico relating to Religion— In company with him is Bishop Walsh residing at Halifax. I had no conversation with Bishop Hughes concerning the object of his visit here, but Mr. Robinson has taken pains to circulate a subscription among the members of the House of Representatives, requesting Mr. Hughes to preach in the Hall of the House of Representatives, next Sunday morning— I subscribed my name to this request, to which the Bishop has assented

I returned this morning several visits that of Mr. J A Rockwell at Coleman’s but he was not at his lodgings—that of Mr. Hilliard of Alabama who was also absent, and that of Mr. Thomas Clingman of North Carolina with whom I sat and conversed for some time As my carriage stopt at the door of his lodgings Mr. Mangum the Senator from North Carolina came out, and stopped and spoke to me as I was seated in the Carriage— I went also to the House of Representatives Clerks Office before returning home. I received a Tragedy of five Acts called Arnold or the Treason of West point by Horatio Hubbel printed at Philadelphia, in the present year 1847. The copy of it sent to me is addressed to me in manuscript, but without the signature of the author or indicating from whom it comes— It is Dedicated to the American People as a fragment of their History— As a Drama it is constructed according to the rules of art composed in blank verse, but without anything in it, in my opinion worthy to be remembered. I do not know that it would be possible to compose a Tragedy upon that subject which could remain as a work for a duration of Ages. It is perhaps the most extraordinary incident of the American Revolution and as a part of its History possesses deep interest—the History of it as a narrative has been written and published in French by B. De Marbois who was a man of Letters, and Secretary of the
Minister of France, the Chevalier De La Luzerne in company with whom I came in the Summer of 1779. from L’Orient to Boston in the French Frigate La Sensible This work of Marbois is exceedingly well written, in a style studied to resemble that of Salust in his History with the War with Jugurtha. The subject has been very indifferently treated by all the English and American Historians of the Revolution and not remarkably well by the Italian Botan I believe this subject susceptible of a great Historical work, but doubt whether it will ever find a writer equal to it—

At eleven oclock this morning I attended in company with Miss Agniel, my Grand Daughter Mary Louisa and Isaac Hull, at the Hall of the House of Representatives where the Roman Catholic Bishop of New York, an Irishman by the name of Hughes performed Divine Service. He was the second Roman Catholic Bishop, native of Ireland whom I had heard preach in that Hall. he was arrayed in his episcopal garments but so simplified as scarcely to be distinguished from a simple Clergymans gown. He began the Service by stating the substance of a prayer taken from the Mass Book, and embracing the objects of most of the Prayers in the Book of the Church of England, a prayer of blessing upon the race of man in general, and upon the several Classes of men including the President of the United States Magistrates, and the people of all Classes and Denominations— He then read from the 20th. Chapter of St Mathews from the 20th. to the 28th. verse.

At the House the appointment of the standing Committees was announced. Samuel F Vinton is Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, John A. Rockwell of Connecticut of the Committee of Claims, Washington Hunt
of New York, of the Committee of Commerce, Jacob Collamer of Vermont, of the Public Lands, William L Goggin of Virginia, of the Post Offices and Post Roads, John G. Chapman of Maryland, of the District of Columbia, Joseph. R. Ingersoll of Pennsylvania, on the Judiciary, and Daniel. P. King of Massachusetts, on Revolutionary Claims, Andrew Stuart of Pennsylvania of Manufactures, Hugh White of New York, of Agriculture, andP. Gentry of Tennessee, of Indian Affairs, John M Botts of Virginia, Military Affairs, Thomas. B. King of Georgia on Naval Affairs, Truman Smith of Connecticut of Foreign Affairs, and C. B. Smith of Indiana on the Territories, All the Chairmen, of the standing Committees are whigs—of the Speakers creed and he has made me Chairman of the Joint Library Committee on the part of the House, with Wm. B. Preston of Virginia and Henry. C. Murphy of New York. The whigs not of the Speakers School, are all placed, in the most insignificant positions on the Committees. an arrangement which has given much dissatisfaction. There was scarcely any transaction of business, the House having received very early in the day a message from the Senate announcing the decease of Jabez. W. Huntington Senator from Connecticut who died after a short illness at his residence in Norwich on the 2d. day of November last. upon which Mr. John. A. Rockwell, made the usual obituary Eulogium, and offered the usual resolutions, adopted on such occasions, concluding with one that the House do adjourn, which was accordingly done— Of all the existing members of the Senate, Mr. Huntington was the one with whom I most thoroughly sympathized in sentiment, and I consider his loss, as a grievous misfortune to the Country— His successor appointed by the Governor of Conn during the recess of the Legislature, of that State, is Mr. Roger S. Baldwin, who was my associate in the Trial before the Supreme Court, in the case of the negroes, of
the Schooner Amistad.

At the opening of the Session of the House this morning Joshua. R. Giddings of Ohio requested the attention of the House to an attack, in the Public Press upon him, in a newspaper called the Daily National Whig on account of his vote for Speaker—and he sent the paper to the Clerk with the Article entitled Party treachery against Giddings, Tuck, Palfrey. Et id genus omne. The article was very abusive, threatening to exhibit a full statement of the course of those Whigs who deserted their Party on the occasion of the election of their Officers of the House, and to send two thousand copies of the National Whig in which it appears, into each of the Districts of those gentlemen in order that their Constituencies may be made acquainted with the facts in the case— Giddings stated that this Paper was established professing to be for the purpose of promoting the election of General Taylor, that the Editor not avowing himself was one of John Tyler’s appointments and was said to be connected with certain members of the House— Mr. Giddings in a summary manner justified himself for his votes, and disclaimed any intention to implicate the Whig Party in this infamous attempt to brow beat and intimidate the members of the Party. No reply was made, but it was manifest that this was the purpose of the establishment of the Daily National Whig— When I first came to the City, a man came to me proposing to me to subscribe for this Paper. I asked him who was to be its Editor, which he declined to answer, and I accordingly declined to subscribe for it. Whether the Speaker has any concern in the establishment of the Paper is not fully established. Charles. J. Ingersoll, made a Report in part from the Select Committee of the Revisal of the Rules, which was made
the special order for Thursday next— A Memorial from James Munroe of the City of New York was presented contesting the election of David S. Jackson the sitting member— A Chaplain, for the present Session was elected. Mr. Levin nominated the Rev R. W. Cushman, Baptist, Mr. Ashmun nominated the Rev Orville Dewey Congregationalist I nominated the Rev. R. R. Gurley. Mr. McLean nominated the Rev J. M. McJilton Protestant Episcopalian Mr. Staunton nominated Rev Levi R. Reese, Methodist John Pettit of Indiana, and Wm. Sawyer of Ohio were excused from voting. At the third trial Mr. Gurley received 102 votes and Mr. Cushman 100. Gurley was therefore elected as the Chaplain of the House for the present Session— The House adjourned before three o’clock. And last Evening the information was received of the decease at New York of the late Chancellor Kent.

In the Senate this morning John C. Calhoun, offered two Resolutions against the conquest of Mexico either to hold it as a Province or to incorporate it in the Union and that no line of policy in the further prosecution of the War, should be adopted which may lead to consequences so disastrous— To be discussed hereafter. In the House Mr. Vinton’s proposition to establish an additional standing Committee in Internal Commerce between the States was fiercely contested by Robert. B. Rhett of South Carolina, and debated by several others. A message was received from the President assigning his reasons for what is called the pocket veto. This Bill being an Act to provide for the continuing certain works in the Territory of Wisconsin, and for other purposes past the two Houses of Congress, and was presented to the President on the last day of the last Session. He neither signed, nor returned it. in consequence of which it failed to
become a Law— This message contained his reasons for not signing the Bill. A debate ensued, upon what was to be done with the message which was not ultimately decided— Isaac. E. Holmes of Charleston South Carolina, offered Resolutions similar to those presented by Mr. Calhoun, to the Senate.

In the SenateFoot, one of the Senators from the state of Mississippi announced the decease of his Colleague Jesse Speight who died at his residence in Mississippi on the first day of May last. I had known him from the year 1829. to 1837. as a member of the House of Representatives from the state of North Carolina In the latter year he removed to Mississippi and was immediately and successively elected to both Houses of the Legislature of that State, and then to the Senate of the United States— He appears to have been of a remarkably attractive personal character of which however he exhibited no evidence in Public life. The usual Obituary Resolutions including that of immediate adjournment were passed in the Senate and announced to the House— There the special order of the day was the consideration of the Report of the Select Committee to revise the Rules and Orders of the House—which report like those of all similar Committees which I have known since I became a member of the House, are exemplifications of that state described in Paradise Lost where [“]chaos umpire sits, and by decision more embroils the fray”— The special order was postponed till tomorrow at the motion of Charles. J. Ingersoll. The debate upon the message of the President received yesterday assigning his reasons for withholding his assent to the River and Harbour Bill. of the last Session, was resumed, and Schenck of Ohio and John Pettit of Indiana made speeches against it. Before Pettit concluded
the message from the Senate was received announcing the decease of Jesse Speight—whereupon Jacob Thompson of Mississippi made an Eulogistic speech concluding with the usual Resolutions, including by the immediate adjournment of the House.

The Senate adjourned yesterday over till next Monday. At the House the special order of the day was again postponed—and John Pettit of Indiana made a personal explanation, charging with falsehood the Report in the Union newspaper of Pettit’s speech made yesterday— Mr. Botts of Virginia introduced a Joint Resolution, authorizing the Postmaster General to renew his engagement with certain Virginia Rail Roads. Mr. Meade of Virginia announced the decease of George C. Dromgoole late and long a member of this House, who died on the 27th. of April last at his residence in the County of Brunswick a few days after he had received intelligence of his re-election to Congress. Mr. Meade pronounced his Eulogy, which he estimated at a high but very indulgent standard He concluded with the usual resolutions and the House adjourned.

In the House the Report of the Select Committee for the revisal of the Rules was the Special Order for debate and the usual effect of the appointment of such Committees was again exemplified that is to say it only made the subject of the rules more complicated than it was The first discussion was about what is called the hour Rule, that is the limitation of an hour for the time allowed to every member to speak upon any subject in Debate. The select Committee first proposed an extent of the limitation from an
hour to an hour and a half, and secondly they proposed a substitute for the hour Rule allowing each member who proposes any measure another hour to close the Debate which of course establishes an inequality between the members some to be indulged with two hours and others to be confined to one. This introduced a long Debate, which was closed by a re adoption of the hour rule with the proviso that in closing debates every member shall be allowed five minutes to explain in Committee of the whole any Amendment he may offer—and by adopting a further Rule that members may address the House from the Clerks Desk or from a place near the Speakers Chair instead of from his own Seat. An additional Rule was adopted that except during the last ten days of the Session the Speaker shall not entertain a motion to suspend the Rules of the House except on Monday of every week, and except a motion for going into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. Another Rule proposed was that when the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, or a Committee of the whole House finds itself without a Quorum, the Chairman shall cause the Role of the House to be called, and thereupon the Committee shall rise and the Chairman shall Report the names of the absentees which shall be entered in the Journal— Other Rules were proposed and among the rest one that in addition to the other standing Committees of the House there shall be one called the Smithsonian Committee whose duty it shall be to superintend the affairs of the Smithsonian Institution. This again introduced a long Debate all which was closed by a Resolution offered by Charles. J. Ingersoll that
the Rules of the House at the last Congress with the modifications of them, this day adopted be henceforth the Rules and regulations of this House during this Session of Congress. And so ends the undertaking to simplyfy and improve the Rules for this time— The House adjourned about three oclock.

I attended Public Worship this morning in the Hall of the House of Representatives where the Chaplain of the House Mr. Gurley preached from John 1.16. “And of his fulness have all we received and grace for grace. 17. For the Law was given by Moses, but grace and truth came by Jesus Christ”— And in the Afternoon at Saint Johns.

In the House the Speaker called this morning for Petitions. I presented a Petition ofpraying for Peace with Mexico and moved its reference to a Select Committee Lynn Boyd moved its reference to the Committee of Foreign Affairs. Lynn Boyd modified his motion to be referred to the Committee on Military Affairs. it was finally referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs— I presented also the petition of Photius Kavasales. praying he might be authorized to change his name to that of Fisk. which was contested and laid over under the Rule. I presented also the Petitions of John Mitchell for a Pension, referred to the Committee on Invalid Pension, and of John. P. Andrews of Salem for Peace with Mexico, referred to the Committee of Foreign Affairs. A great number of Petitions were presented and numerous Resolutions were offered, one by one that the same number of Pages be employed
for the use of the House, that were employed previous to the 27th. Congress to wit 12. I offered this Resolution at the request of the Door Keeper Mr. Horner and it was adopted without opposition— Isaac E. Holmes moved a Resolution that the monies deposited with the several States and Territories as a Loan from the Treasury of the Surplus Revenue being now called for, by the Government of the United States, before resort being had to another Loan. It was referred to the Committee of Ways and Means. Thomas Butler King moved that it shall be the duty of the Speaker to remove the Desks from the Hall and that a large table be placed in front of the Clerks Desk for the use of the members. This was an imitation of the English House of Commons—but the Resolution was laid on the Table. Gentry moved a request to the President to communicate to the House the instructions given to John Slidell as minister Plenipotentiary and Embassador Extraordinary to the Government of Mexico. Schenck moved a long Resolution of enquiry for copies of all orders and communications with the Government of New Mexico— John Pettit moved two Resolutions of the right of Congress to make internal improvements for purposes of War and Navigation— He moved the Previous Question. Simms of South Carolina moved to lay them both on the Table— Charles. J. Ingersoll called for a division of the Question, to take separate votes on laying each Resolution on the Table. Pettit claimed it was not in order to separate them— The Speaker decided that the Question was divisible and might be taken separately on each Question
From this decision Simms of South Carolina appealed, and the decision was reversed by Tellers 63 to 87. The Question of laying both the Resolutions on the Table was rejected by yeas and nays 70. to 124. The Previous Question was not seconded, Howell Cobb of Georgia declared his intention, to Debate, the Resolutions and they were laid over, under the Rule— Wm. A. Richardson of Illinois, moved his Resolutions, in favor of the War with Mexico—during the discussion of which, the House adjourned.

In the Senate of the United States Daniel S. Dickinson the Senator from New York and John C. Calhoun, from South Carolina have offered opposite Resolutions respecting the termination of the War with Mexico. Dickinson in favor of extensive Acquisition of Territory—and Calhoun against extensive addition Territory— The Discussion of them was this day commenced and made the Order for the 4th. of January. In the House the call for Petitions was continued. Joshua R. Giddings, presented a memorial with 18 Citizens of the District of Columbia representing that the Slave Trade is now carried on, to a large extent, and praying that all Laws authorizing or sanctioning such Trade with the District may be repealed— Giddings moved to refer the memorial to the Committee on the Judiciary Clingman of North Carolina moved to lay the Petition on the Table, which was taken by yeas and nays—announced to be a tie 97 and 97. The Speaker then gave the casting vote against laying it on the Table— Chapman moved its reference to the Committee on the District of Columbia but Cobb of Georgia declared his
to Debate the Memorial and it was laid over under the Rule. numerous Bills were introduced and notices of Bills to be introduced hereafter. I offered a Resolution which was adopted, that the Secretary of State Report to the House the state of the Claims of Aaron Leggett on the Government of Mexico decided under the Convention of the 11th. of April 1839. and such action as may have been had and the papers relating thereto in the Department of State since the Report upon them of the Committee on Foreign Affairs in August 1842. referring them for farther consideration to the Executive Branch of the Government— The House adjourned about three oclock—
